Expectation1: Ensure compliance with safety and regulatory standards
Situation1: A recently updated standard will apply to the upcoming release, and evidence of conformity is required
Situation2: The polls close for good tonight, and this moment is the voter’s sole opportunity to present the mandated ID.
Story:
I stared at the clock on my monitor, heart pounding. As an engineer, I was responsible for submitting the final compliance report for our new product release. The updated safety standard had just come into effect, and my manager made it clear: no evidence of conformity, no launch. I scrolled through the checklist, double-checking every document, knowing the auditors would scrutinize every detail. 

But my phone buzzed with a reminder: polls close at 8 p.m. sharp. Today was the last day to vote, and I had to bring my government-issued ID—no exceptions. I glanced at my bag, realizing my ID was at home, a 30-minute drive away. If I left now, I’d miss the window to finalize the compliance upload. If I stayed, I’d lose my only chance to vote in this critical election. 

My mind raced, torn between my duty to my team and my responsibility as a citizen. Both roles demanded my presence, both with consequences I couldn’t ignore. I sat frozen, the weight of expectation pressing in from all sides, unable to move as the minutes slipped away.
